excerpt: Basilica dating to the 4th century that is marked by some Christians as the site of Jesus's tomb.
detail_description: The Church of the Holy Sepulchre is a historic basilica dating back to the 4th century and is believed by some Christians to be the site of Jesus's tomb. The church holds immense historical significance, with its roots tracing back through thousands of years of Jewish history, from Byzantine Rule to the British Mandate. Visitors can experience a whirlwind tour that includes stops at iconic sites like the Western Wall, Via Dolorosa, and Bethlehem.
name: Church of the Holy Sepulchre

excerpt: Art & archaeology museum with prehistoric to modern collections, including the Dead Sea Scrolls.
detail_description: The Israel Museum in Jerusalem is a must-visit for art and archaeology enthusiasts. It houses an extensive collection that spans from prehistoric artifacts to modern art, including the famous Dead Sea Scrolls. The museum also features archaeological exhibits showcasing the region's history, biblical and religious artifacts, and a diverse range of art pieces from modern Israeli works to ancient American art.
name: The Israel Museum, Jerusalem

excerpt: Historic mountain referenced in the Old & New Testaments of the Bible, now a cemetery & sacred spot.
detail_description: The Mount of Olives, a historic mountain referenced in the Old and New Testaments of the Bible, holds significant religious and cultural importance. It has been a sacred spot for centuries and is now home to several important churches and holy sites. Notably, it was mentioned in the Scriptures as King David's escape route during his son's rebellion and later in the prophets. In the New Testament, it is where Jesus taught his disciples, wept over Jerusalem, and ascended into heaven.
name: Mt of Olives

excerpt: Memorial complex to Holocaust victims with guided tours of a museum displaying historical exhibits.
detail_description: Yad Vashem, established in 1953, is a memorial complex dedicated to honoring the six million Jewish victims of the Holocaust. It also pays tribute to the bravery of Jewish resistance fighters and non-Jews who risked their lives to save Jews during that time. Located on Har Hazikaron in Jerusalem, it includes monuments, a historical museum, an archive and research center for documenting the Holocaust, and an educational facility. The museum's exhibitions are emotionally moving and flawlessly organized.
name: Yad Vashem

excerpt: Medieval citadel on the site of forts dating back 2,000 years & a museum of Jerusalem's history.
detail_description: Tower of David is a medieval citadel located on the site of forts dating back 2,000 years and serves as a museum showcasing the history of Jerusalem. The citadel has witnessed numerous historical events in Israel, from ancient times through the centuries up to the present day. It features Knights Halls in the Hospitaller quarter and offers insights into Jewish history from Byzantine Rule to the British Mandate.
name: Tower of David

excerpt: Surrounded by ancient walls, the Old City is home to holy sites such as the Western Wall, Dome of the Rock Islamic shrine, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, which dates to the 4th century. Shops and markets selling prayer shawls, rosaries, and ceramics fill busy alleys, while food stalls serve falafel, pita, and fresh-squeezed juice. In a medieval citadel, the Tower of David museum chronicles the city’s history.
detail_description: The Old City, surrounded by ancient walls, is a melting pot of cultures and religions. It's home to holy sites like the Western Wall, Dome of the Rock Islamic shrine, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. The area is divided into four quarters - Jewish, Muslim, Armenian, and Christian - each with its own unique atmosphere and attractions.
name: Old City

excerpt: Iconic gold-topped Islamic shrine built around 690AD with huge relevance to both Christians & Jews.
detail_description: The Dome of the Rock is an iconic Islamic shrine with a gold-topped structure built around 690AD. It holds great significance for Christians and Jews as well. Situated on the Temple Mount, it was completed under the rule of Umayyad Caliph Abd al-Malik and has been covered in gold twice in the 20th century. Despite common misconceptions, it is not a mosque but rather a shrine to the Foundation Stone, important in both Torah and Islamic beliefs.
name: Dome of the Rock

excerpt: Remnant of the ancient wall of the Temple courtyard, a sacred site of Jewish prayer & pilgrimage.
detail_description: The Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall, is a significant site in the Jewish Quarter of Jerusalem. It is a remnant of the ancient wall that surrounded the Temple courtyard and holds great religious and historical importance for Jewish people. Visitors can witness worshippers reciting verses or leaving written prayers in its stones. The wall was built around 2000 years ago to support Temple Mount, and after the destruction of the Second Temple, it became a place for lamentation.
name: Western Wall

excerpt: Shops now line this stone street believed to be part of Jesus' path on the way to his crucifixion.
detail_description: Via Dolorosa, also known as the "way of suffering," is a stone street in Jerusalem that is believed to be part of the path Jesus took on his way to crucifixion. This historic route has been attracting Christian pilgrims since the fourth century and remains an important site for those seeking to understand the significance of Jerusalem in Christianity.
name: Via Dolorosa

detail_description: The Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall, is a significant site in Old Jerusalem with deep Jewish religious and historical importance. Visitors can explore the adjacent Western Wall Tunnel, an underground network constructed during King Herod's expansion of the Temple Mount. The tunnel offers a fascinating glimpse into ancient architectural marvels and costs 35 ILS per person for entry.
name: Western wall

excerpt: Ancient tomb & surrounding gardens believed by some to be site of resurrection of Jesus Christ.
detail_description: The Garden Tomb Jerusalem is a site surrounded by gardens and believed by some to be the location of Jesus Christ's resurrection. The history of the Land of Israel is rich, spanning from ancient times to the present day, with events such as Byzantine Rule and the British Mandate shaping its story. Located in Jerusalem City Centre, this historical site offers visitors a chance to explore its significance within walking distance of other attractions like Machane Yehuda Market and Damascus Gate.
name: The Garden Tomb Jerusalem

excerpt: This olive garden, now adjacent to a Franciscan church, figures prominently into Christian texts.
detail_description: The Garden of Gethsemane, located at the base of the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem, is a remarkable site steeped in Christian heritage and historical depth. This serene olive grove is renowned as the location where Jesus prayed prior to his arrest, making it a significant pilgrimage destination for many Christians. The garden boasts ancient olive trees that are thought to be over 900 years old, offering visitors a tangible link to its biblical narrative.
name: Gethsemane

detail_description: Temple Mount, also known as Har Ha-Bayit in Hebrew and Al-Haram al-Sharif in Islam, is a significant historical site dominated by the raised platform. It was the location of the First and Second Temples and now houses Muslim holy structures like the Dome of the Rock and Al-Aqsa Mosque. The area within its walls resembles a typical Middle Eastern city with mosques, churches, synagogues, courtyards, gardens, and bazaars.
name: Temple Mount

detail_description: The City of David in Jerusalem is an ancient site that dates back thousands of years and lies beneath the modern city. It offers a glimpse into the historical roots of the region. Hezekiah's Tunnel, stretching 530 meters, showcases innovative water transportation methods from ancient times. Visitors can explore both attractions through organized tours such as the Jerusalem Underground Tour.
name: City of David

excerpt: Hill rising to 2,500 ft., with a Benedictine abbey, Holocaust museum, cemetery & biblical landmarks.
detail_description: Mt Zion is a 2,500 ft. hill in Israel that holds significant historical and religious landmarks. It features a Benedictine abbey, Holocaust museum, cemetery, and biblical sites. The area has a rich history dating back to ancient times, with events recorded in the Bible and spanning thousands of years of Jewish history under various rulers such as Byzantine, Persian, Crusaders, Arabs, and Ottomans.
name: Mt Zion

excerpt: Jerusalem is a city in the Southern Levant, on a plateau in the Judaean Mountains between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea. It is one of the oldest cities in the world, and is considered holy to the three major Abrahamic religions—Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Jerusalem, located in the Southern Levant on a plateau in the Judaean Mountains, is one of the oldest cities and holds great religious significance for Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. The city is currently experiencing tensions with Israeli military raids in towns south of Nablus following an attack that resulted in casualties. Meanwhile, Passover celebrations bring Israelis together for a seder meal to commemorate their freedom.
name: Jerusalem

excerpt: Reconstructed synagogue founded in the early 1700s featuring a huge Torah ark & views from its dome.
detail_description: The Hurva Synagogue, also known as The Ruin Synagogue, is a reconstructed synagogue located in the Jewish Quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem. Originally established in the early 18th century and later destroyed and rebuilt, it holds historical significance. The synagogue was rebuilt in its original 19th-century style in 2010 by architect Nahum Meltzer to recapture its former glory. It features a huge Torah ark and offers stunning views from its dome.
name: בית כנסת החורבה - Hurva Synagogue

excerpt: Domed, Islamic place of worship linked to Muhammad & rebuilt over the 8th to 11th centuries.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Jerusalem's Old City, Al-Aqsa Mosque stands as a magnificent testament to Islamic architecture and spirituality. Revered as the third holiest site in Islam, this domed mosque has deep historical roots, having been rebuilt between the 8th and 11th centuries. It occupies a significant location on Temple Mount, which is also sacred to Judaism due to its connection with the ancient Temple.
name: Al-Aqsa Mosque

excerpt: Overlooking the Old City, Mount of Olives is home to many ancient Christian shrines and churches, including the Chapel of the Ascension, built on the site where many Christians and Muslims believe Jesus Christ ascended. Visitors descend to an underground cave to reach the Tomb of the Prophets, and stroll under millennia-old olive trees in the Garden of Gethsemane. A handful of eateries serve pastries and falafels.
detail_description: Situated above the Old City, Mount of Olives is a significant site for various ancient Christian landmarks and churches. The Chapel of the Ascension, believed to be where Jesus ascended, and the Tomb of the Prophets are among these sacred places. Visitors can also explore the Garden of Gethsemane with its ancient olive trees.
name: Mount of Olives

detail_description: Jaffa Gate is a charming stone entrance to Jerusalem's Old City, dating back to 1538. Its unique L shape served as a defensive feature, and the sand-colored blocks exude an air of impenetrability. The gate leads to the Christian Quarter on one side and the Armenian Quarter on the other, attracting a constant flow of pedestrians under its ancient arch. Visitors can explore traditional markets nearby but should be cautious as prices may vary for tourists.
name: Jaffa Gate

excerpt: Built in 1537, this stone structure is one of the main entrances to the Old City of Jerusalem.
detail_description: Damascus Gate, a historic stone structure dating back to 1537, serves as one of the primary entrances to Jerusalem's Old City. It is located near significant religious sites such as the believed crucifixion and resurrection site of Jesus. Annually, an evening of Christmas carols in English, Hebrew, and Arabic takes place here. Additionally, nearby attractions include Ein Kerem village with its ancient holy sites like the Church of the Visitation and the Church of John the Baptist.
name: Damascus Gate

excerpt: Israel's parliament, with free themed tours (drop-in or pre-booked) offered in multiple languages.
detail_description: The Knesset, Israel's unicameral parliament, is housed in a modern and functional building designed by Joseph Klarwin. The structure features pillars that resemble the colonnades of Greco-Roman architecture, symbolizing civic ideals. Initially funded by the Rothschild family, the building has undergone architectural changes to accommodate the growing parliamentary membership and government staff. Visitors can enjoy themed tours in multiple languages and explore its interior decor modifications over the years.
name: The Knesset
address: משכן הכנסת, Eliezer Kaplan St 1, Jerusalem, 9195000, Israel

excerpt: Legendary burial site of biblical King David, housed in a centuries-old structure with scenic views.
detail_description: The King David's Tomb is a centuries-old structure located in the City of David which has scenic views. It contains the burial site of biblical King David, as well as other important religious sites such as Davids Well, Shepherds Field and the Pools of Solomon.
name: King David's Tomb

excerpt: Religious artifacts fill this ancient tomb believed to be the burial site of the Virgin Mary.
detail_description: Nestled in the serene Kidron Valley at the base of the Mount of Olives, the Tomb of the Virgin Mary is a significant religious site steeped in history. This ancient tomb, believed to be where the Virgin Mary was laid to rest, is surrounded by other notable landmarks such as the Garden of Gethsemane and various churches.
name: Tomb of the Virgin

excerpt: Ein Kerem is a charming hillside village famed for its centuries-old holy sites. These include the Church of St. John the Baptist, containing a cave said to be the saint’s birthplace, and Mary’s Spring, where the Virgin Mary is believed to have drunk. Dotting the village’s narrow streets are galleries and shops selling hand-painted tiles and jewelry, plus quaint cafes and stylish Mediterranean restaurants.
detail_description: Ein Karem is a picturesque hillside village known for its ancient religious sites and charming atmosphere. Visitors can explore the Church of St. John the Baptist, which houses a cave believed to be the saint's birthplace, and Mary's Spring, where it is said that the Virgin Mary drank water. The narrow streets are lined with galleries, shops selling hand-painted tiles and jewelry, cozy cafes, and stylish Mediterranean restaurants.
name: Ein Karem

excerpt: Shops, restaurants, live concerts & cultural events offered at a 19th-century train station.
detail_description: The First Station in Jerusalem is a vibrant cultural and entertainment hub located at a 19th-century train station. Renovated in recent years, it offers an array of experiences including local food, organic produce shopping, boutiques with local and international goods, live concerts, and themed events. This historical complex is situated in the heart of Jerusalem and features a bustling restaurant scene. Open seven days a week, it's an ideal destination for visitors seeking to immerse themselves in the local vibe and culture.
name: The First Station

excerpt: This bird-focused, nature preserve features guided tours, a visitor's center & a gift shop.
detail_description: Located in the heart of Jerusalem, just below the Knesset, the Jerusalem Bird Observatory is a nature preserve and bird-focused site that offers guided tours, a visitor's center, and a gift shop. The observatory has been open for about twenty years and features a research center alongside its visitor facilities. It also boasts Israel's first living building as part of its visitor experience enhancement.
name: Jerusalem Bird Observatory

excerpt: Catholic church built in 1924, with colorful mosaics & a rock where Jesus is said to have prayed.
detail_description: The Church of All Nations, also known as The Basilica of Agony, is a Catholic church located on the Mount of Olives. It is renowned for enshrining the rock where Jesus is believed to have prayed before his arrest. Constructed in 1924 with contributions from twelve different nations, the church features colorful mosaics representing these nations and boasts a tranquil location within the Garden of Gethsemane.
name: Church of All Nations

excerpt: Beit David was the fourth Jewish neighborhood outside the walls of Jerusalem. This courtyard neighborhood was established in 1873. Wikipedia.
detail_description: The City of David is an ancient neighborhood established in 1873, located outside the walls of Jerusalem. It includes Mount Zion, the Room of the Last Supper, Tomb of King David, and Church of the Dormition. The area also features the Garden Tomb, a site believed by some to be Jesus' burial place. This archaeological site dates back over 6,000 years and was part of Jerusalem's urban area during the time of the Temples.
name: City of David

excerpt: The hilltop Jewish Quarter is a small neighborhood known for ancient landmarks such as the Western Wall, a holy Jewish site from the 1st century. Restaurants are set near historic places of worship like the reconstructed Hurva and Ramban synagogues, while museums such as Siebenberg House showcase relics from King David's reign. Shops line the colonnaded Cardo Maximus, a street from Roman and Byzantine times.
detail_description: The Jewish Quarter, located in the Old City of Jerusalem, is a historic neighborhood filled with ancient landmarks and religious sites. Visitors can explore the Western Wall, Hurva Synagogue, and Ramban Synagogue while also enjoying kosher fast-food spots and traditional bakeries along Jewish Quarter Road. Despite being partially destroyed during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War, the area has been rebuilt and now offers a mix of historic charm and modern amenities.
name: The Jewish Quarter

excerpt: A maze of narrow alleys winds through the Muslim Quarter, home to Islamic, Jewish and Christian landmarks. In the sprawling Temple Mount courtyard, the Byzantine-era Dome of the Rock is one of Islam's holiest places. Little Western Wall is a Jewish religious site near the Iron Gate, while medieval St. Anne's Church sits near the Lions' Gate. An ancient street bazaar sells food, clothes and religious souvenirs.
detail_description: The Muslim Quarter is a historic area in Jerusalem, characterized by its maze of narrow alleys and diverse religious landmarks. It is home to the Temple Mount courtyard, where the iconic Dome of the Rock stands as one of Islam's holiest sites. Nearby, visitors can explore the Little Western Wall and St. Anne's Church, as well as an ancient street bazaar offering various goods and religious souvenirs.
name: Muslim Quarter

excerpt: Bethlehem is a Palestinian town south of Jerusalem in the West Bank. The biblical birthplace of Jesus, it’s a major Christian pilgrimage destination. The birth is marked by an inlaid silver star in a grotto under the 6th-century Church of the Nativity, which shares Manger Square with the 15th-century Church of St. Catherine and the 1860 Mosque of Omar.
detail_description: Bethlehem, a town in the West Bank, is known as the biblical birthplace of Jesus and is a significant Christian pilgrimage destination. The Church of the Nativity, with its inlaid silver star marking the birthplace, is a major focus for Christian veneration. Despite scholarly debate about Jesus' actual birthplace, Bethlehem continues to attract pilgrims from around the world. Visitors can also explore other nearby sites such as Manger Square and the Church of St. Catherine.
name: Bethlehem

detail_description: Via Dolorosa, also known as the Way of Sorrow, is a historic route in Jerusalem's Old City that holds significant religious importance for Christians. This path is believed to be the route Jesus took from Pontius Pilate's sentencing to Golgotha, where he was crucified. Today, Via Dolorosa is lined with ancient stone buildings and souvenir shops, making it a bustling and lively street rather than the quiet path depicted in Christian hymns.
name: Via Dolorosa

excerpt: Eastern Orthodox monastery built in the 11th century, with a museum, library & gift shop.
detail_description: The Monastery of the Cross, an Eastern Orthodox monastery dating back to the 11th century, is a legendary monument hidden in the hills. It resembles Petra's Treasury but is larger and was originally a Nabataean tomb. The name comes from crosses carved inside, indicating its use as a Byzantine church. A rock-cut path with over 800 steps leads from the Basin Restaurant to this ancient site.
name: Monastery of the Cross

excerpt: Hill featuring the National Civil Cemetery, the National Garden, views of Jerusalem & more.
detail_description: Mount Herzl is a significant hill in Jerusalem, featuring the National Civil Cemetery and the National Garden. It offers stunning views of the city. The site is home to the remains of Theodor Herzl, the founder of Zionism, and includes a museum showcasing a reconstruction of his library and study. Additionally, it serves as the final resting place for notable figures such as commanders in the Israeli army, prime ministers, presidents, and Yitzhak Rabin.
name: Mount Herzl

excerpt: University garden & research center with a conservatory, geographical zones & many bonsai trees.
name: Jerusalem Botanical Gardens

detail_description: When visiting the Old City of Jerusalem, take a stroll to the eastern side where you can descend into the picturesque Kidron Valley and ascend to the Mount of Olives. The breathtaking view and beautiful churches on the mountainside are sure to leave you in awe.
name: Kidron Valley

excerpt: Restored Romanesque church built by the Crusaders in 1138 & sought out by choirs for its acoustics.
detail_description: St. Anne's Church in Jerusalem is a restored Romanesque church with a rich history dating back to its completion in 1138 by the Crusaders. Situated near the beginning of the Via Dolorosa, it holds significance as the traditional birthplace of the Virgin Mary. The church's remarkable Romanesque architecture features high arches and an austere design, representing medieval European architecture in Jerusalem.
name: St. Anne's Church, Jerusalem

excerpt: Antonio Barluzzi designed this church as a pilgrimage site near to a Byzantine tomb complex.
detail_description: Nestled on the iconic Mount of Olives, Dominus Flevit Church is a remarkable pilgrimage site designed by Antonio Barluzzi in the mid-1950s. Its unique architecture resembles a tear, symbolizing the sorrow Jesus felt as he approached Jerusalem and wept over its fate.
name: Dominus Flevit Church

excerpt: The ancient Christian Quarter centers on the 4th-century Church of the Holy Sepulchre, where millions of pilgrims visit holy sites such as the traditional site of Jesus Christ's crucifixion and his tomb. Historic Damascus Gate is within leafy Mish'ol HaPninim Garden, not far from the famous Via Dolorosa processional route. Antique shops, cafes and restaurants cluster around the storied Muristan market complex.
detail_description: The Christian Quarter in Jerusalem's Old City is a historic area centered around the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, a significant pilgrimage site believed to encompass Jesus Christ's crucifixion and tomb. The quarter features the leafy Mish'ol HaPninim Garden near the iconic Damascus Gate and the renowned Via Dolorosa processional route. Antique shops, cafes, and restaurants are clustered around the storied Muristan market complex.
name: Christian Quarter

excerpt: The Armenian Quarter is one of the four sectors of the walled Old City of Jerusalem. Located in the southwestern corner of the Old City, it can be accessed through the Zion Gate and Jaffa Gate. It occupies an area of 0.126 km², which is 14% of the Old City's total. In 2007, it had a population of 2,424. Wikipedia.
detail_description: The Armenian Quarter, one of the four sections within the Old City of Jerusalem, is situated in the southwestern part and covers 0.126 km², making up 14% of the Old City's total area. With a population of 2,424 as of 2007, it offers access through the Zion Gate and Jaffa Gate. The quarter is home to St James Cathedral and visitors can catch prayers there from 3-3:30 pm daily except Sundays.
name: Armenian Quarter

excerpt: Striking, 19th-century, Russian Orthodox church with golden cupolas & murals by Sergei Ivanov.
detail_description: The Church of Mary Magdalene, situated on the Mount of Olives, is a stunning 19th-century Russian Orthodox church adorned with seven golden onion-shaped domes. It was constructed in honor of Empress Maria Alexandrovna of Russia by Tsar Alexander III. The church holds religious significance as it commemorates Mary Magdalene, who according to Mark's gospel, was the first person to witness the resurrected Christ.
name: Church of Mary Magdalene

excerpt: Landmark stone gate constructed in 1537, leading pedestrians to the Western Wall.
detail_description: The Dung Gate is an ancient landmark constructed in 1537 that leads pedestrians to the Western Wall. It is situated not far from the Wailing Wall and provides access to various archaeological sites such as the City of David, where Jerusalem began 3000-4000 years ago. This area has many underground paths, some of which are submerged in water, allowing visitors to explore the historical exhibition at the Davidson Center located next to the Wailing Wall.
name: Dung Gate

excerpt: Prominent Lutheran church built at the end of the 19th century, with a tall, 7-story bell tower.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Jerusalem's Christian Quarter, the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer is a striking example of 19th-century architecture. Completed in 1898 with funding from the German Empire, this church features a remarkable seven-story bell tower that rises majestically above the ancient cityscape. While its chapel may appear simple and unadorned, it is complemented by a unique cloister that adds to its charm.
name: Lutheran Church of the Redeemer

excerpt: Children's science museum providing interactive exhibits, workshops & performances.
detail_description: Bloomfield Science Museum, located near the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in the Givat Ram neighborhood, offers an interactive and educational experience for families. The museum features colorful hands-on exhibits designed to make science fun for children and young adults. Visitors can explore a variety of subjects including mind-boggling optical illusions and the workings of electricity through changing exhibitions on various technological and scientific topics.
name: Bloomfield Science Museum

excerpt: One of the Old City's 8, this famous medieval gate was built in 1540 & leads toward Mount Zion.
detail_description: Zion Gate is one of the eight gates in the Old City of Jerusalem, dating back to 1540. It leads towards Mount Zion and holds significant historical and religious importance for Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. The gate bears scars from past conflicts, including bullet holes from the 1948 War of Independence. Today, it allows vehicle passage, but visitors should be cautious when crossing. The gate's rich history makes it a must-visit attraction for those interested in exploring Jerusalem's cultural heritage.
name: Zion Gate

detail_description: Old City Bazaar, located within the historic walls of the Old City in Jerusalem, offers a unique and diverse shopping experience. Divided into different quarters - Jewish, Christian, Muslim, and Armenian - the market is filled with a wide array of traditional items such as religious artifacts, handmade crafts, spices, and souvenirs. The restored Cardo serves as the main street for vendors selling Judaica ceremonial art and other goods.
name: Old City Bazaar
address: Shuk ha-Tsaba'im St. Next to Church of Holy Sepulchre, Jerusalem

detail_description: Mahane Yehuda Market in Jerusalem is a bustling and vibrant food market with hundreds of stalls offering local produce, coffee, teas, spices, dried fruits, nuts, fish, meat, cheese, olives and baked goods. Recently revitalized with new boutiques and trendy cafes added to the mix. The market is a lively scene with tourists mingling among locals doing their shopping. It's recommended to visit on Friday mid-morning to early afternoon when locals stock up before Shabbat begins.
name: Mahane Yehuda Market

excerpt: Exhibits trace Islamic art from the 7th century onwards & include ceramics, prints & ornate watches.
detail_description: The Museum of Islamic Art, situated in the Katamon neighborhood near the Jerusalem Theater, showcases a diverse collection of Islamic art dating back to the 7th century. The museum's nine galleries are arranged chronologically and feature an extensive array of artifacts including ceramics, prints, ornate watches, gold and silver objects, jewelry, musical instruments, calligraphy, glassware, metalwork and more. Additionally, it houses a comprehensive archive of antique watches and clocks.
name: Museum of Islamic Art

excerpt: Guided tours are available of this 5-acre, underground limestone quarry dating from ancient times.
detail_description: Discover the enigmatic Zedekiah's Cave, also known as Solomon's Quarries, a colossal 5-acre underground limestone quarry in Jerusalem. This ancient man-made cavern dates back 2000 years and is located beneath Damascus Gate. The cave offers guided tours for visitors to explore its numerous corridors, halls, and passages that were once used by sectarians and freemasons. It is a hidden realm of mystery and wonder where history, legend, and sheer awe collide.
name: Zedekiah's Cave
